key_insight: A streaming-friendly diffusion framework enables real-time, interactive full-body human avatars by redesigning diffusion pipelines for causal, low-latency generation without sacrificing visual fidelity.
problem_solved: Diffusion-based avatar generation is typically non-causal and computationally heavy, preventing real-time streaming and limiting interactive systems to head-and-shoulder outputs; this work addresses low-latency, streaming-compatible generation and extends control to full-body gestures and motion.
method: Two-stage architecture: a lightweight streaming front-end for fast temporal conditioning and a higher-fidelity refinement stage that operates incrementally to preserve quality.
Causal/streaming diffusion modifications: enforce temporal causality and operate on frame chunks or recurrent states to enable online, frame-by-frame generation with bounded latency.

Efficiency optimizations and control interfaces: model compression, early-exit or progressive refinement strategies plus multimodal control inputs (pose, audio, text) for interactive full-body motion.
impact: Enables deployable, low-latency interactive avatars for telepresence, games, and virtual production, lowering compute barriers for real-time digital-human applications and opening diffusion models to streaming use-cases.
